captions.text:
Hello, I'm Tom Hiddleston, recording this
from my kitchen.

This is just to say that I'm on my last day,
my fifth day, of the Live Below The Line challenge

The challenge is to live off a pound a day
of food and drink for 5 days, to raise awareness

for the 1 billion children all over the world
in the poorest countries and communities who
have to live off that every single day.

You too can do it on the 29th April to the
3rd May (2014) - just go to http://livebelowtheline.com/uk

In the meantime, it's time for my lunch, which
as you'll see is the glorious and simple pleasure
Never has a baked potato looked so good.
That probably cost me about 10 pence.

Thank you so much for all your support. It's
time to eat.

title: Tom Hiddleston Live Below The Line Day 5

comments.text:
Tom Hiddleston is undoubtedly a beautiful man in the physical sense but his 
mind, his personality, his... his very being is even more beautiful. Its 
his kindness, his eloquence, his elegance, his intelligence, his 
thoughtfulness, his honesty, his optimism, his love of life and the pure 
compassion he radiates that makes me admire him the way I do. I can only 
aspire to be more like him.﻿

comments.author: Nessa Fitzgerald

comments.text:
There have been times where I've purposely gone hungry just so I can put 
gas in my vehicle so I can go to work. Then I became pregnant and it made 
things a whole lot different. I still struggle every day to have proper 
nutrition so my daughter can grow, even with now getting food stamps (they 
give me $58 a month, not counting my unborn child as a person), and WIC so 
I can drink milk and eat fruit/vegetables for a week. 2 if I stretch it. 

Government assistance isn't enough. I'm grateful I'm getting something, but 
it's still hard. Thanks Tom for showing this awareness. If there is the 
time where I can only afford food FOR my child, I'm making sure she eats. I 
don't have to. As long as she grows, I'll be fine.﻿

comments.text:
While I admire his effort to raise awareness of child poverty, what's the 
purpose of encouraging others to live below the line?  Is it a way to diet? 
Is it to get people to live within their means or less than that?  Because 
there's a difference between living below the line and living within your 
means and there can be serious detrimental effects to one's health if one 
tries to live like for a long period of time. ﻿

No, sorry, but I think you misunderstood all this. The purpose of this 
challenge is to raise awareness about life conditions of many human beings, 
to understand what really means to have such a limited budget for food and 
drink.
I can guarantee you that doesn't have the same impact if you read this in 
an articule but if you experience it. What this is all about, is to make us 
understand how lucky we are for live in abundance and comfort, and of 
course, to makes us want to help in any way we can.
Please forgive my English :)

comments.text:
I don't need a challenge to do this.  That is my life.  Sadly.  On a 
personal note I think it would be a good thing if all the politicians in 
our government had to live like this for a certain amount of time to better 
understand what it's like for those who have no choice to.﻿
comments.author: Cynical Cthulhu

comments.text:
+Ivana Radic Depends on where you live. Some public kitchens or food 
pantries don't have enough supplies to give to everybody, they struggle 
everyday to get donations. Also many people don't know their resources and 
don't have proper transportation to get to these places and carry home 
groceries. If you live in very rural conditions, or very urban, it's hard 
to locate food kitchens (pantries) that will help you out. Especially in 
the south. I know because I've been in situations where I needed to go to 
one. Thankfully I have a car (barely a car since its on its last brake) 
that was able to get me to where I needed to go. I have many friends who 
can barely get by having trouble finding proper food pantries. Just because 
they are there, doesn't mean people have access to them!
comments.author: allie bolen

comments.text:
It's quite public in the news here (Canada, not sure about the US).  I 
think there was a lot of cultural misunderstanding in how to best merge 
some very distinct ethnicities across a vast landscape.  The perception 
that residential schools were out of malice against the people first living 
here is not quite accurate.  Children back in Europe experienced similar 
"educations" during the 1800s as well.  That however does not justify what 
happened as the trauma persists through generations.
comments.author: Crystal Ward

comments.text:
+Crystal Ward Unfortunately true.  I wonder how many people realize there 
are people in North America who are starving to death.  Would they believe 
you if you told them?
comments.author: Cynical Cthulhu

comments.text:
+iammadness people in developed countries have a hard time believing there 
are poor people living near them...It is much easier to accept that poverty 
is someone else's problem.  Canada has the wealthiest middle class in the 
world, and yet there are First Nations people who do have access to the 
internet (fixed economic costs - one time only, accessible in schhols or 
library) and struggle to bring in good food to their reserve.  People would 
rather believe that if a person is in that state they are unmotivated.
comments.author: Crystal Ward

comments.text: +Supercalifragilis7 You'd be surprised.  Still, it's about not giving up.
comments.author: Cynical Cthulhu

comments.text:
but one would think that with access to internet where there is so much

comments.author: Celine StClair

comments.text:
+Supercalifragilis7 For food, yes.  Also, for the argument of how one can 
have a computer while being poor have you ever heard of loans?  I got one 
that took years to pay off where others can just go drop a wad and get a 
new one and when this one dies it would not be easy to replace.  It's also 
possible to receive things as a gift from richer friends.  Some of the 
upgrades in mine have been donated parts from friends who got better ones 
for theirs.  Some people survive on donations from others believe it or 
not.  Never assume.  It makes you look bad.
comments.author: Cynical Cthulhu

comments.author: Pilar Harry

comments.text:
You wanna know what below the line is Mr. Hiddleston? It's your parents 
having 6 children and your father not working one day since the first one 
was born. It's never setting foot inside a class room in your entire life. 
It's going to work full time, 40+ hours a week too support your siblings. 
It's moving over 30 times in19 years because your father has such severe 
mental problems that he believes God speaks to him and tells him not too 
stay in one place too long or the Devil will get him. It's being homeless 
twice as a tennager for months at a time. It's hearing your little brother 
cry himself too sleep because he hadn't eaten in 2 days. And on top of all 
of the insanity I've just described, your father beats your mother. Every. 
Single. Night. And no one does anything too stop it because there's no one 
too tell. I'm 24 years old sir, and I have seen some of the worst things 
this world has too offer. You, my good man, could not fit what I have seen 
in my 24 years into every one of your 32. What you did is nice, but there 
are so many lines too live under. I wish hunger was the only one I've had 
too endure.﻿
comments.author: Naomi Baughman

comments.text:
Whoa!  Hey now.  I, too, have known pain and suffering in my life.  But 
it's no reason to lash out with resentment against someone who is truly a 
kind and thoughtful human being.  He is at least trying to raise awareness 
of other's suffering and that is more than one can say of many out there 
more privileged than the average human being.
comments.author: Cynical Cthulhu

comments.text: where are days 1-4?﻿
comments.author: bebe ori

comments.text:
Tom's an amazing guy, it is fantastic that he does so much work with 
children's charities!  Food, and the money to buy it with, is something too 
many of us take for granted.  I think this is something that everyone could 
stand to engage in, just to breed empathy if nothing else.  There is enough 
food in the world to feed everyone; but there is not enough money to pay 
for it.  And that is a pretty poor excuse to let a child go hungry.

Also - yes, Tom is extremely handsome, yes, I replayed the video about 15 
times to get a good look at his kitchen, and no, I don't think there's 
anything wrong with talking about it!  (In fact, I think it was a genius 
move to set the video there, because it ensures that people will watch it 
and spread it!  Well done, marketing team!)﻿
comments.author: darkangelscruffy

comments.author: Natalie Francesco

comments.text:
@antenoraaaa, I completely agree with your opinion. Though it is a good 
act, it will end up in 5 days. The most important that people must 
understand is the fact that people who lives "below the line" have no 
choice. And that happens in every country.

I'm from Spain and nobody would think about hangry people here. With our 
economical situation, there is a lot of people having a lot of troubles 
only to feed their families. Personally I know a boy whith 2 children, and 
he only eats 2 times a day: breakfast, and something in the evening, 
because his wife is jobless and he doesn't earn enough money to feed 
everyone and pay the bills. His children think that daddy eats a lot 
outdoors and that he is never hangry.

And this is happening in the famous and gorgeous Barcelona.

And that is only an example of the reality near us, nearer than we think﻿

than just entertain,lol.There would need to be way more to be done than 
just not contributing to movies. Some people don't go see them anyway and 
spend their money on other things that are harmful to themselves and the 
environment,even without contributing to big corporations either. & yes 
definitely points to Thomas,lol.

comments.text:
